description: From Middle English ferre, fer, Old English feor, feorr, from Proto-Germanic *ferrai.

adjectives.description: far (comparative farther or further, superlative farthest or furthest or farthermost or furthermost)

examples: He went to a far land.
See those two mountains? The ogre lives on the far one.
He moved to the far end of the state. She remained at this end.

entries.meaning: Extreme, as measured from some central or neutral position.
examples: They are on the far right on this issue.

entries.meaning: Extreme, as a difference in nature or quality.
(programming, not comparable) Outside the currently selected segment in a segmented memory architecture.
examples: far heap; far memory; far pointer

adverbs.description: far (comparative farther or further, superlative farthest or furthest)

entries.meaning: To, from or over a great distance in space, time or other extent.
examples: You have all come far and you will go farther.
He built a time machine and travelled far into the future.
Over time, his views moved far away from mine.

entries.meaning: Very much; by a great amount.
examples: He was far richer than we'd thought.
The expense far exceeds what I expected.
I saw a tiny figure far below me.

verbs.description: far (third-person singular simple present fars, present participle farring, simple past and past participle farred)

examples: But I wish he'd been farred before he ever came near this house, with his “Please Betty” this, and “Please Betty” that, and drinking up our new milk as if he'd been a cat. I hate such beguiling ways.

description: From Latin far. Doublet of farro.

entries.meaning: Spelt (a type of wheat, Triticum spelta), especially in the context of Roman use of it.
examples: A cataplasm made from any meal is heating, whether it be of wheat, or of far, or barley, or bitter vetch, ...

entries.meaning: (UK, dialect) A litter of piglets; a farrow.
